comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The Library of Congress is currently posting photos from the Bain News Agency's 1914 photostream. The 1920 date on the (glass) negative represents a later re-use of the image by Bain.

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: What's the story behind this photo? Were the guns confiscated from criminals? Were they no longer needed as evidence? Why not melt them down as scrap metal? The rifle barrels look like they've been deliberately bent.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Some police agencies nowadays do send the confiscated guns to be melted down for scrap -- often on an annual basis. Usually the agency collecting the guns from various jurisdictions is a State Police force. The guns have been used in crimes, or seized during domestic quarrels, or voluntarily surrendered by members of the public. The order to destroy them comes from a judge, often at the end of a criminal trial. Sometimes, if a weapon is unusual, a police agency will ask the judge for permission to keep the weapon for training purposes, or for use by a SWAT team. In Connecticut, until 1992, confiscated guns were not scrapped, but sold to the public at auction.
